Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This was a survey course that was better taught than intro psych

I learned so much about the ways in which we think, including decision-making, reasoning fallacies, moral judgement, confirmation bias, language, intelligence, etc. The material was very relevant to daily life.
I learned a lot about how people make decisions and the biases that we exhibit on a day to day basis.
I learned more about personal and Social Psychology. Very interesting.

This course taught me a lot of practical knowledge regarding how people make decisions! I found this course to be really applicable in daily life situations, and recognizing reasoning fallacies in the real world has been incredibly interesting for me.
Learned a lot about how we think, biases we have, fallacies we make, and how to think critically in various ways.

This was the first psychology course I took at Yale, and I definitely came away from it having learned a lot about the heuristics that people use to make decisions and the biases that make them irrational. This is definitely a class with real-world applications; it changed the way I think about the world.
I was exposed to a good amount of psychological studies on thinking and reasoning, with excellent discussions on ways to improve thinking skills.
basic overview of many subjects in psychology

This class was amazing. Professor Ahn is great and we learned all about human thought and how it was rational or irrational. It is very interesting because it gives you a look into why we think the way we do.
I learned SO MUCH that I have been taking into account in my everyday learning. I actively think about whether I am "thinking" wrong and I think it has really helped me as a student and as a person.

I learned a lot from this class. There is a good amount of material covered in the course but its very interesting and so much of it is applicable to life. You learn about a lot of mistakes people make every day due to certain reasoning fallacies and then you see them more and more in your own life but that allows you to fix them. So essentially if you take this course its kind of like getting a cheat sheet to your mind. I have definitely applied strategies I have learned in this class outside the classroom.
I learned about the many ways in which humans think and fail to act rationally.

As a thinking class, I believe I have acquired many skills that can be used in every day life when wanting to think rationally, morally and many more. With examples of studies presented well for each phenomena, students were able to know well the course material. As it includes making students interact in the lecture, everyday examples of thinking fallacies and how to avoid them presented as well as organized in a fun way, it has been able to teach me a lot about how to think to achieve good results.
We learned a lot about reasoning fallacies in the way we think and heuristics we use that sometimes make us make irrational choices.

I learned not only why different thinking fallacies occur, but different ways to help lessen those fallacies. I also learned how to better learn at the lectures and how to facilitate necessary information from interesting facts.
ability to think, discuss normative reasoning, point out reasoning fallacies in real life examples
I learned about rational behavior and how to make better choices

We learned about different components of thinking and the errors that occur during thinking processes. Concepts were always presented with empirical studies, which enforced the use of evidence to support conclusions.

This course taught me about the many ways in which I think irrationally and the biases that affect everyday life. Through the use of experiments and studies, I learned so much about how people make decisions on a daily basis.
This class was so interesting and fun! I liked going to the lectures and I thought the material was relevant and useful to learn.
Got a much better understanding of the way people think--exactly as advertised!
Intro to behavioral sciences, how people think, why humans are irrational

Really cool class; I liked how the knowledge we learned was observable in real life. "Thinking" sounds really vague, but it's about decision making, biases, creativity, and logic, and it's super interesting.

Learned how to think!
How to spot reasoning fallacies, heuristics, etc.
And how to correct them.
How to approach problems rationally.
Fundamental psych in some of the most interesting topics - a survey course.
This course helped me to understand more about my own behavior and those around me.

I learned a vast amount of information about the realm of psychology when analyzing human rationality, and I found it was very interesting and many of the topics could be applied to my daily life. I really loved the topics this course offered.
The different ways the human brain approaches situations and evaluates the world. Fascinating subject.
I learned a lot about how the human brain works and the fallacies that people often make.

I learned a lot about a wide variety of topics in human thinking. I gained a new perspective on my previous-learned psychology knowledge, and I took away some valuable lessons on how to improve my own life using the knowledge we gained in the class.

I learnt a lot of psychological knowledge related to how humans think. With each lecture focusing on a different theme, I was able to learn from a wide range of materials and retained a lot of information through the weekly quizzes.

I learned a lot about the biases we make as humans and was able to see them happen in everyday life. I also learned some valuable skills that are applicable to my school work and other activities. This class was a class in which we learned real, practical things that we could apply to our lives.
Definitely learned how to think smarter. I use the knowledge from this class in my every day life to help make better personal decisions, and to communicate with others.

This course covered a lot of ground. The syllabus lays it out pretty clearly-its a lot of topics. I certainly got a broad overview of different aspects of human (and a little bit of animal) cognition, many of our consistent irrationalities, and models of what normative thought should be. The structure of exams also forces you to synthesize information into concise bits. I think I took away a lot of ideas that can help me in other courses as well.

Thinking investigated why our most common reasoning fallacies occur. The class gave me tools to recognize why I or someone I know made a decision or assumed a certain opinion - and how to investigate whether or not that choice was rational or reasonable. I really appreciated how our thinking processes were presented in terms of normative and descriptive terms, allowing room for irrational behavior to still make sense. This class is so applicable to real life and I was always talking about it to my friends.
I learned a lot about different reasoning biases and other concepts in psychology related to how people think.  I also learned how to read and process the results of a psychology experiment or study.

This class focused on a broad spectrum of topics, from behavioral economics to concept of self to linguistic determinism to the potential detriments of intelligence. This was the first psychology class I've taken at Yale, and it was truly incredible. I really feel like I learned a lot, not only about different heuristics people use when making judgments (as taught by the course), but about how psychology works and how research is conducted. The final paper, a research proposal, helped me get a sense of the complexities of how research is conducted.
This course was well-taught the review sheets before each exam were incredibly helpful
This course is wonderfully taught, well-organized, and extremely engaging and interesting. I did not find any weaknesses in the course.
A very well taught course with plenty of demonstrations and class interactions to keep even the driest of material fun and interesting.
I thought that the teaching style and the structure were excellent.
It is a good course and well organized.

I think this course was incredibly strong and taught students a variety of studies regarding decision-making and reasoning fallacies. I honestly can not think of a weakness. The quizzes at first were a bit nerve-wracking, but I think students got more accustomed to them as the semester went on.
Lectures are GREAT!! Always engaging, super interesting and lively. Weakness are maybe that review guides didn't always map onto the tests 100%, but not a major issue!

The course places a heavy emphasis on a large number of studies conducted that illustrate the various heuristics that we covered, and the exams consist in large part of regurgitating these studies onto the paper. However, that being said, the material was very interesting and the guest lectures were mostly engaging, and Professor Ahn is hilarious.

I loved everything about the design and context of this course. The professor was the best! 

The only thing I would add is maybe having an extra points project.
extremely fun and easy; could have required more engagement, i.e. the study guides basically told us exactly what would be on the exam so ironically we didn't have to do a ton of thinking

This class was very engaging, the quizzes every lecture were stressful and at times I was very worried that I didn't understand the material well enough. The review guides we got before each test were very helpful. It was nice to know what topics would be covered and not having the fear that I would forget something while studying.

Overall, this course was incredibly solid in terms of the way it was taught. The quizzes were somewhat annoying at times, but in the end they only did help me, so I can't really complain. One thing that was frustrating though is how they were structured -- I saw multiple people either start early and use the lecture slides to cheat or continue doing it after they left and asking others for answer. I can't really think of any other weaknesses.
No weaknesses!!! Such a good class. The everyday quizzes were really helpful. The exams were super dense is the only thing, but I actually enjoyed taking them.

It was a great class. I honestly don't think I would change much. Maybe assign the essay during the semester instead of at the end since it isn't worth very much? It could be used as a way to explore the topics that were covered (but I think having it at the end of the course its fine as well. )
The course was well designed to make sure we remembered concepts after each classes, but it was difficult to access the instructor and TFs, because office hours only occurred before an exam.

Strengths: There are weekly quizzes that make sure students have been attending their lectures attentively as well as 3 midterms which has been able to reduce the stress of student in the final week. Another thing is how course was well organized and contains much content supported with surplus example that have enabled students to understand it fully.

This was a wonderful class. Professor Ahn made every lecture incredibly engaging. There is a quiz every class which really helps you solidify the material and also is a good boost for your grade. Most of the topics are really interesting and the guest lectures are awesome.

Strengths: Lectures were always interesting, quizzes accurately reflected what went over in lectures, professor is very nice.

Weaknesses: None.
no big weaknesses, the strength is the structure of the course--a quiz after each lecture, very clear review sheets, available professor and TF.
The class was fun and interactive. The subject was very interesting!

Strengths: variety of interesting topics, engaging and fun class, low workload, lectures were very clear

Weaknesses: a bit heavy focus on studies for exams (seemed like memorization)
This course was very straightforward with a lighter workload, but I learned so much.

It was helpful that the classes were recorded. I also liked that there were quizzes for the class, because they helped me pay close attention to the lectures and helped me understand them better. I also really liked that we got review sheets for the exams, which made studying for them much more manageable.
Strengths: engaging lectures, no required readings, reasonable exams, and short final paper.  Weaknesses: can't really think of any
Really interesting lectures, manageable assessments (daily quizzes) , easy tests with thorough study guides provided by the professor

The quizzes don't really do much--they're more a test of how much you were paying attention, not a device that helps with studying (especially because the quizzes share little in common with the exams). You will rely almost 100% on lecture notes and at times powerpoints for the exams. Professor Ahn is a great lecturer!

The lectures were super interesting, and so was the material covered.
The expectations were clear from the beginning: we knew what to do to succeed.
The quizzes were a good way to keep students alert in class.
The exams were fun to study for.
The powerpoints were nice and helpful.
Only weakness: the guest lecturers were nowhere as good or interesting as Professor Anh!
The course is extremely well taught. Professor Ahn is one of the best professors I have ever had.

This course was almost perfect. I absolutely LOVED professor Ahn, and I think the course topics were fantastic. Honestly, I think less guest lecturers would be better--even though some of them were really good, none were really as good as Professor Ahn. Additionally, I think the final paper was a good weight, along with the tests. I really loved this course and looked forward to going every Tuesday and Thursday.
Amazing teachers, TA's and material
The course lectures were highly engaging and I really appreciated the use of Piazza for a sort of collaborative studying for tests.

The course didn't really have any significant weaknesses, in my opinion. The course was very organized and well-run, and I learned a LOT. Professor Ahn put a lot of time and effort into the class, and it truly showed.

The course focuses on providing a comprehensive picture on the topic of thinking, and it was able to do that. Guest lecturers also added even more fun to the classes. The lectures are engaging and course materials were conveyed in a very clear and interesting way. It would be great if the course could allow even more room for thinking, such as practically applying the concepts into our real lives.

Strengths: Very clearly laid out with three non-cumulative tests, quizzes at the end of every class, and a final paper. We were always given a review sheet before the test that detailed exactly what would be on the test. Professor Ahn is an amazing, funny, and riveting lecturer who does her best to help her students understand the material and truly learn. The grading is very fair, help is always available, and Professor Ahn really wants to help her students succeed. 

Weaknesses: A lot of material was covered to the point that it was difficult to study for the tests at times even though they were non-cumulative. However, it was still manageable, and we were always given a review sheet of the topics that will be on the test.

If you pay attention in class and study the study guides you can do well. Professor Ahn is amazing and very charismatic. The test are a bit long and for people who are even slightly slower it can be tough to finish on time.

Strengths: Fantastic Professor if prof. Ahn is teaching it. Really well set up to force you to learn material. A lot of fascinating topics. Great guest lecturers. Great access to Professor Ahn. 
Weaknesses: I think it would have been nice to have some more connections from lecture to lecture sometimes. Obviously they were there in some capacity, but it often felt like every time we started a new topic we just left the old one completely behind. Also I think the paper was a little strangeit was worth so little it slightly deincentivized workin hard on it, and it kinda came out of nowhere.

As a lecture class, Thinking excelled mostly due to its lecturer. Professor Ahn, the DUS of Psychology, prepared an insane amount of time for each class - and it showed. She made complicated concepts accessible to a wide range of students by making the information relatable and fun - there were many great videos, graphs, clip-art, sound effects that always kept the class laughing. Prof. Ahn is brash and bold, and she knows her stuff. 

Id say the courses biggest weakness is the exam/grading structure: 3 huge exams worth 75% of your grade, 1 final paper (7%), and 18 low-stress mini quizzes (18%) - one at the end of each class. Putting so much weight on the 3 midterms was very stressful, as each had way too many questions to answer in the allotted time. I saw many people struggle to finish and I always felt like I didnt have time to even think through something before having to spit it out on the page. I knew this going in and took it Credit/D, which worked very well in my favor. The material is important and useful, and I appreciated being able to sit back and soak it up rather than writing every single tidbit so I could do well on the exams.

Professor Ahn was amazing.  The lectures were extremely interesting, the quizzes after class were fair, and the final paper assignment was interesting and manageable.  The biggest strength of this class was probably the lecture quality, each lecture was clear, informative and engaging.  It was also really helpful to have all of the lectures recorded.  One weakness of the course was probably that there were no mandatory readings.  The workload of this course was pretty low, and one or two mandatory readings a week, not much, may have helped us go deeper into some of the material.  I know that she assigned optional readings, but as students, when we're trying to balance the workload of many classes, often the optional stuff gets ignored.  One other weakness of the course, was that the exams were so long, that I felt that it encouraged a lot of memorizing of answers.  We were given the exam questions in advance, but we had to write so quickly during the exam that we basically just memorized stuff in advance, which didn't feel like it contributed much to my learning.
Incredibly engaging, real world implications, best professor ever

This course was, in a word, perfect. It was excellently structured, creatively designed, and meticulously prepared. Professor Ahn really cares about making each joke land (and she's really funny, so it worked) and about making sure students really learn. To that end, there is a quiz at the end of every class to make sure students understood the material. I thought this would be annoying, but it turned out to actually be very helpful in figuring out what to focus on studying in the future. It also increased memory retention for the class.

The syllabus is also very forgiving. Even though the tests are worth 25% of your final grade each, a review sheet was provided beforehand which was absolutely essential in terms of preparing for the test. If you studied the review sheet, it was very easy to do well on the test.

What's more, Professor AHn invites many guest speakers, who give lectures on their fields of study. It's truly incredible to see how many different fields of psychology there are, and how profoundly exciting they can be to the people involved in their research.

I can't really think of any weaknesses of this course. It was a deeply inspiring and educational class to take, and I couldn't be happier that I took it.
Yes! this class is perfect for non psych and psych majors; straightforward and interesting

I would absolutely recommend this course! Professor Ahn's lectures are very engaging, interesting, and funny. The material is very clearly presented, with well-organized Powerpoint slides that are uploaded onto Canvas before every class. Each concept we learned was presented with studies / anecdotes / examples from daily life, so material was easy to understand. The course material is extremely interesting for psych and non-psych majors alike, because it is so relevant to our daily lives. I will definitely apply the things we learned to my life.

Take this class if you want a class where you don't have much outside work but still learn all the information. Super interesting and relevant topics that will force you to be more aware about these concepts in your daily interactions with people.
I absolutely would; it was very interesting and felt very applicable to my life.
Yes, you do learn useful and interesting new concepts and theories.
Yes definitely!! Even with background in psychology, I felt like I learned from this class and actually will be able to take that knowledge into future years.

Yes!! Super interesting, Prof. Ahn is AMAZING and it's not too much work except studying for tests and the final paper. Definitely come to class and you'll do fine on the daily quizzes (even though that sounds scary at first, they aren't bad).

Yes, take this class if you are interested in how people make decisions/behavioral economics. It is not difficult to do well in either, as long as you put in some effort to prepare for the three exams.
Yes this class was amazing and very applicable to everything.

I would! This course is both a challenging and rewarding course. The learning you gain in the end has no limits. It goes beyond anyone's comfort zones. I loved it and I'm already applying what I learned in my real life.
great fifth credit, super easy and fun and prof ahn is hilarious
Yes! Definitely would recommend this class! Professor Ahn is amazing.

I would definitely recommend this course! Prof. Ahn is an absolutely amazing instructor -- so engaging and thoughtful! This course is definitely structured in a way where you can do well if you put in even a basic amount of effort. And Prof. Ahn and the TF's are beyond willing to help you if you're struggling. The exams are literally the same as the review sheets; if you take the time to do the review sheet and memorize the answers, you should also do well on the exams. 10/10 course that is fairly easy despite a few chunks of work during exam times and really interesting content.
YES ABSOLUTELY!! Best class I've taken at Yale or anywhere for that matter.

yes, I would 100% recommend this class. There is so much you can take away from it even if you are not a psych major. It is interesting and teaches you a lot about how we think and why we make certain mistakes in reasoning. (once you know these things you can start to see everything you learned in class at work in the world which is pretty cool)
Yes, while it may not seem like a lot of work, it is a course in which you need to stay engaged in order to do well in.

Yes, I would recommend it very much. It is a course that is well organized and thought by the best professor. Even if not part of Psychology major track, the course is composed of things that can be applied to any major and any lifestyle. As a first year who took the course, it has been able to change the way I think about things and even made better adjustments to my future in terms of major and other life events.

Yes, absolutely. This class is incredibly interesting and applicable to your general life. You don't have to be particularly interested in psychology to find this interesting, it appeals to a lot of different areas. There is also no hw assigned so it's not a lot of work, but you still learn a ton. I think I learned much more in this class than average even though it was less than average work. It would make a good fifth class.
The course is very interesting, the material is straightforward, you don't have homework, and as long as you know the studies and fallacies you will do well on the midterms.
Yes such a great class. It was interesting and relevant. The teacher is amazing.

Yes, if you are interested in learning a variety of topics involving how we think. The course doesn't go very deep into each topic, but you cover a lot. There is no work outside of class except for exam studying. Professor Ahn made lectures fun and engaging!

I would 100% recommend this course to another student. The material in this course is so engaging and Professor Ahn adds her own spunk to it. The material covered in this course is so versatile and I definitely became a better student because of it.

I would recommend this course to just about anyone. It was interesting and fun to attend lecture. The workload wasnt bad at all and the topics were presented with a great structure, in which the professor sumarized studies that supported each phenomenon she described. The exams were easy to prepare for because she told you in advance everything you needed to know, your only job was to learn it. There was no ambiguity to how we would be graded in exams or the paper.
Yes, Professor Ahn is so funny and the material is very interesting!

Definitely recommend!! Was a good social science credit that wasn't too hard but taught me a lot. Prof. Ahn is an engaging lecturer, and I always enjoyed going to class.  If you go to class and study for a couple hours before each of the three exams, you'll do great.  No required readings or problem sets, just a short online quiz at the end of each lecture.  Prof. Ahn and the TFs made themselves quite available for questions and personal interactions., so I always felt like they really cared for the students. Overall, low workload, fun to take, and high payoff in terms of my new understanding of how people think.

I loved this course. As a non-major, I got introduced into psych through this class. Prof. Ahn presents the material in such as interesting, yet understandable way. This class really got me interested in behavioural sciences!

Not a lot of work, BUT a lot of studying. The first 1/3 (i.e. all material before the first midterm) is tough, but after the that the class gets better (you are more used to the exams and the material is much more engaging). Prof. Ahn is great, and she is definitely a professor you should take a class with.

Absolutely! Amazing class. Super fun. What I imagined college classes to be like.
Learned some things that will stay with me all my life and that I can now  bring up in conversations to sound smart and interesting.
yes
I would absolutely recommend this course to everyone.

I cannot express how much I would recommend this course. It was possibly the best course I've ever taken in my life, as Professor Ahn was so funny and intellectual and was always there for her students. She was fantastic and the course was fantastic. I can't recommend it enough.
Yes, most interesting class of my semester.

I would recommend this course because the content is very interesting and the workload is presented in such a way that it isn't overwhelming, but still gives students sufficient practice with the content. Daily quizzes after lecture instead of homework really helped lessen stress in general, and having study guides for tests were amazing.

I would recommend this course to anybody interested in psychology/cognitive science. It is similar to Intro Cogsci in that it is sort of a survey course of many topics in cognitive science. Professor Ahn is a great teacher and her lectures are always fun and interesting. There is no reading for the course which is great, but the workload is still fairly high with 3 exams and a final paper. That said, the exams are pretty fair, and if you use the review sheets and start studying ahead of time you should be fine.

Take this course! You'll get exposure to many interesting topics in psychology, and you'll walk away from each lecture really feeling like you learned a lot. Professor Ahn really cares about her students and takes time to learn as many names as possible, and she finds many ways to make each class fun. The class is organized and very low-stress, and I think this class provides a fabulous way to dabble in psychology if it's not something you plan to major in.

Yes! All the concept chosen by Professor Ahn connects closely to our daily lives, and if you are new to psychology, this is definitely a course that includes a lot of interesting theories and experiments in psychology!

I definitely would recommend this course to another student! You definitely have to keep with the material and study ahead of time, but Professor Ahn really tries to make it as easy as possible to study and learn the material, and she is simply just a wonderful lecturer and person overall!
I would recommend this course. The material is interesting, the professor is great, but you do have to go to class and pay attention before you study for the exams.

This is undoubtedly one of the best courses I have taken at Yale. Professor Ahn is utterly fantastic, and probably the first professor I have genuinely gotten to know well even though this was a lecture course! It has almost no day to day work so you dont have to sacrifice time from your schedule for it (although you do have to go to absolutely every lecture since theres a quiz, but lecture is so enjoyable you will want to go.), but you will nevertheless learn a ton. Professor Ahn has a dog she brings to class sometimes so theres that bonus. Shes also very easy to get to know and genuinely interested in geting to know everyone in the class. Exams are straightforward and the grading is as generous as it gets. If youve ever vaguely wondered about why you make dumb decisions or if something you thought makes sense, take this class. This class was legitimately FUN to attend (I am not a psych person). I actually looked forward to lecture as I always left feeling great, like I was learning cool stuff and I had a professor who cared about me, which did wonders for me on days when other classes (cough cough MATH 120) were making me question every last person who ever claimed college is enjoyable and Yale has good teaching. So yeah TAKE THIS CLASS!

Definitely, though I doubt itll be taught again soon. If DUS Ahn teaches ANYTHING in the next few years, TAKE THAT CLASS. Consider taking it Cr/D depending on the grading structure, but please take it. She makes so much information accessible to different types of people and got our class really pumped about psychology. You may even get a visit from her lovely dog!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student.  The material was extremely interesting, and extremely relevant to our daily lives as it gave me a lot of insight into all of the biases that happen when we process information and try to make decisions.  Professor Ahn is a very good lecturer.  Her lectures are clear, interesting, and funny.  She also cares deeply about her students and is constantly trying to get feedback on how things went and whether we were understanding concepts.  The workload of this class was also on the low side, which was nice given that I took it senior fall, and needed to focus on the senior requirement for my major.  Would definitely recommend if you're looking for an interesting class, that's useful to you later in life, and that has a manageable workload.
YES!!

Absolutely!!! I would recommend this course to anyone who has any burgeoning interest in psychology, or simply wants to expand their knowledge of the field. But to be honest, I don't know if I would recommend it if it were taught by anyone other than Professor Ahn, who is easily one of the most engaging, adept teachers I've ever had the fortune of learning from.
I would definitely recommend this course!!!
